tool.name: Trim putative adapter sequence
tool.command: FILETYPE1=\$(file '$input1' | cut -d' ' -f2) && FILETYPE2=\$(file '$input2' | cut -d' ' -f2) && if [ \$FILETYPE1 == 'gzip' ]; then PATH1='./forward.fastq.gz'; else PATH1='./forward.fastq'; fi && if [ \$FILETYPE2 == 'gzip' ]; then PATH2='./reverse.fastq.gz'; else PATH2='./reverse.fastq'; fi && ln -s '$input1' \$PATH1 && ln -s '$input2' \$PATH2 && trim_adapters #if '$settings.advanced' == 'advanced' -d '$settings.edit_distance' -f '$settings.fudge' -s '$settings.trim_start' -r '$settings.rc_length' #end if \$PATH1 \$PATH2

param.name: edit_distance
param.label: The maximum edit distance permitted when aligning the paired reads

param.name: fudge
param.label: An arbitrary number of extra bases to trim from the ends of reads

param.name: trim_start
param.label: Trim this number of bases from the start of each sequence

param.name: rc_length
param.label: Use the reverse complement of this number of from the beginning of the reverse read to align reads

tool.help:
**What it does**
The trim_adapters utility is based on a script by Jason Buenrostro. Instead of looking for known adapter sequence, it aligns paired reads to each other and trims off sequence outside the alignment. More precisely, it searches the forward read for the reverse complement of a specified number of bases (20 by default) at the beginning of the reverse read, then falls back to finding the best alignment of the two reads, using the minimum Levenshtein distance between them.
**Input**
It requires 2 inputs: The (optionally gzipped) FASTQ file containing the forward reads and the (optionally gzipped) FASTQ file containing the reverse reads.
**Output**
Generates 2 gzipped fastq files with adapters trimmed.
